questions.question: How is a regular coin flip different from a quantum coin flip?

options.text: A regular coin is always heads or tails, we just don't know which
A quantum coin disappears when flipped
There is no difference at all
A regular coin can be both sides at once

questions.explanation: Exactly! A regular coin is ALWAYS either heads or tails - we just don't know which until we look. A quantum coin is actually BOTH heads and tails simultaneously until measured. That's the key difference! ðŸª™

The qubit being in superposition

options.text: Yes, it's both heads and tails before the flip
No, it's already one side (we just don't know which)
Only if we don't look at it
Coins don't have sides

questions.explanation: Correct! Even before flipping, a regular coin is definitely heads or tails - we just don't know which. Superposition is different - it's genuinely BOTH at once, not just unknown. This is what makes quantum so weird and powerful! ðŸŽ²

questions.question: What is the main difference between a classical bit and a quantum bit (qubit)?

options.text: A bit is faster than a qubit
A qubit can be 0 and 1 at the same time (superposition)
A bit stores more information than a qubit
There is no difference

questions.explanation: Correct! A classical bit is always either 0 OR 1, but a qubit can be in superposition - both 0 AND 1 simultaneously until measured. This is what makes quantum computing special! ðŸŽ¯

questions.question: What happens when you measure a qubit in superposition?

options.text: Nothing happens, it stays the same
It becomes both 0 and 1
The superposition collapses to either 0 or 1
It disappears

questions.explanation: Perfect! Measurement forces the qubit to 'choose' - it collapses from superposition to a definite value (0 or 1). Like catching a spinning coin makes it land on one side! ðŸª™

questions.question: If you flip 100 quantum coins in superposition, what would you expect?

options.text: All 100 would show the same result
About 50 heads and 50 tails
All would remain spinning forever
They would all disappear

questions.explanation: Exactly! Each quantum coin has a 50/50 probability when measured, so with 100 coins you'd expect roughly 50 heads and 50 tails - just like regular coin flips! The difference is quantum coins are truly in both states before measurement. ðŸ“Š

questions.question: Why can't we see superposition in everyday objects?

options.text: We can, we just don't notice it
Superposition only works at tiny scales (atoms, photons)
Superposition doesn't exist
Our eyes are too slow

questions.explanation: Right! Superposition is a quantum effect that only works at incredibly tiny scales. The bigger an object, the harder it is to keep in superposition. That's why we don't see everyday objects in two places at once! ðŸ”¬

options.text: They use less electricity
They can explore many possibilities at once using superposition
They are just faster versions of regular computers
They never make mistakes

questions.explanation: Perfect! Thanks to superposition, quantum computers can explore many solutions simultaneously instead of checking them one by one. This makes them incredibly powerful for certain types of problems! ðŸš€
